title: Political Graft Has a Long History in France
bodyText: It is appropriate to draw attention to the terrible harassment directed at Nathalie Gavarino, the magistrate who oversaw Nicolas Sarkozy's legal proceedings (Editorial, Oct 22). Malfeasance within the French political sphere is hardly a novel phenomenon: Jacques Chirac was found guilty of graft from his time as Paris mayor in the 70s, and Sarkozy's own premier, François Fillon, witnessed his presidential bid collapse in 2017 due to claims of using state funds to pay family members. However, the magnitude and brazenness of Sarkozy's actions distinguish his situation. Not only was he dubbed 'President Bling-Bling' for his flashy lifestyle, but taking money from Muammar Gaddafi marked a new depth. As noted, Marine Le Pen, a top contender for the presidency, is also awaiting an appeal decision regarding corruption. While it is encouraging to see support for his incarceration, his special treatment in jail shows he is no regular inmate. This occurs as the French assembly faces a deadlock. More graft cases could further weaken the political system before the 2027 election. Leaders must rise above this to advance the nation.

title: Connolly’s Major Win Rattles Irish Elite Without Altering Political Landscape
bodyText: The overwhelming triumph of Catherine Connolly in the Irish presidential race is a remarkable political achievement that embarrasses the traditional powers, yet it does not indicate a countrywide shift towards leftist ideologies. Her victory, and particularly its magnitude, was far from certain. Back in July, when she announced her run, she was essentially a solo operator: an independent left-leaning parliamentarian from Galway unknown to many. However, the 68-year-old secured support from a mix of minor opposition groups and tapped into a widespread desire for change.

title: Toronto Blue Jays vs. LA Dodgers: Politics Played Out on the Field
bodyText: Carl von Clausewitz, the Prussian military strategist of the 1800s, famously stated that war is merely 'politics continued by other methods.' As Toronto prepares for a crucial baseball series against a wealthy, star-studded American team, many across Canada feel that sports now reflect this sentiment. Over the past year, Canada has been involved in diplomatic and economic tensions with its traditional ally and largest trading partner.

title: Judicial Politics: Will Spain's PM Weather Corruption Scandals Involving Inner Circle?
bodyText: Even though he has dedicated the last year and a half to protecting his spouse, sibling, political faction, chief prosecutor, and administration from a continuous barrage of graft accusations, Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez retains his wit. Recently, opposition leader Alberto Núñez Feijóo listed the usual charges and implied that Sánchez was more of a defendant than a leader. The pressure remains intense as legal challenges mount against his close allies.

title: A Day of Turmoil in French Politics: Recap and Future Outlook
bodyText: Monday stood out as particularly dramatic within the French government, even compared to recent events. Early in the day, shortly following the unveiling of his new ministry team and under a month into his tenure, Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu stepped down along with his cabinet. Later that afternoon, President Emmanuel Macron requested the departing premier to remain in post for an additional 48 hours in a desperate attempt to navigate the nation's escalating political turmoil.

title: France's Incoming PM Lecornu Vows Significant Departure from Old Political Ways
bodyText: Sébastien Lecornu, the newly appointed Prime Minister of France, has pledged a 'major divergence' from previous political methods as he succeeds the disfavored centrist François Bayrou, who was removed this week due to budget dispute. Lecornu, aged 39, emphasized 'humility' as his guiding principle. He now confronts the challenging job of securing sufficient backing in a fragmented parliament to approve a budget, hoping to avoid the swift ousting that befell his predecessors.

title: Al-Shabaab Leverages Political Division to Retake Somali Territory Amidst Great Fear
bodyText: In early July, during the night, Maryan Abdikadir Geedi concluded that she must leave her little store in Moqokori, located in Somalia's Hiiraan district. Although she was aware of the Islamist militant group al-Shabaab's recent advances, the 46-year-old had wished to remain. Since her marriage in 2013, she had witnessed control of the town shift frequently. 'Power in Moqokori comes and goes like the rain, but this situation felt distinct,' she remarked.

title: Global Political and Faith Leaders Honor Pope Francis
bodyText: Leaders of faith and state across the globe have honored the memory and impact of Pope Francis, following the conclusion of his 12-year pontificate upon his passing in Rome early Monday at age 88. Many highlighted his consistent advocacy for the impoverished and sidelined, as well as his deep dedication to peace and ecological causes. They also recalled his personal warmth and humor as both a man and the head of the Catholic Church.

title: Shifting Political Tides and Polls Suggest New US Stance on Israel. Is it Significant?
bodyText: These connections appeared to be permanent. For 75 years, unwavering backing for Israel—manifested through military assistance and diplomatic support, and reinforced by widespread public agreement—has been a constant in American politics. However, Abdul El-Sayed, a Democratic Senate hopeful in Michigan seen by some as an emerging leader, noticed a shift while campaigning across 58 municipalities in what has historically been a key region.

title: Macron Criticized for Prioritizing Politics in Bayeux Tapestry Lending Decision
bodyText: French specialists have warned that the Bayeux Tapestry is too delicate to move without risking permanent harm, while a petition asking Emmanuel Macron to overturn his 'disastrous' choice to lend the unique artifact to Britain has gathered over 60,000 signatures. In July, the French President announced that the nearly millennial, 70-meter embroidery, depicting William the Conqueror's 1066 victory, would travel across the Channel next year.
